key_points: Hurricane Ida, one of the most powerful hurricanes in U.S. history, ravaged south Louisiana, particularly striking Houma.
Houma's Leonard J. Chabert Medical Center faced significant challenges as Ida hit, with water pouring from the ceiling and structural damage.
The medical center was already overwhelmed with COVID-19 patients due to a brutal surge of cases in the community.
Evacuation or discharge of patients was not feasible due to the severity of their conditions and other hospitals being filled with COVID patients.
The combination of a catastrophic hurricane and the COVID-19 pandemic put unprecedented mental stress on healthcare workers.
Staff at Chabert Medical Center feared the building might collapse and prayed together for protection during the storm.
Terrebonne General Health System, another hospital in Houma, also sustained severe damage, including a collapsing roof and shattered windows.
Both hospitals in Houma had to coordinate a massive evacuation following the damage from the hurricane.
Dr. Chuck Burnell, chief medical officer of Acadian Ambulance, mentioned the difficulty in evacuating over 100 patients, many with COVID, from Terrebonne General.
"Perfect twin-demic" is how the simultaneous occurrence of the hurricane and the COVID-19 surge was described, highlighting its unparalleled impact.
spokespersons: Dr. Chuck Burnell (Chief Medical Officer, Acadian Ambulance)
